intro: Tapinanthus petiolatus, commonly known as the parasitic morning glory, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the roots of other plants to obtain water and nutrients. It belongs to the family Convolvulaceae and is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa. The plant has small, heart-shaped leaves and produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically blue or purple in color. Its stems are often vine-like, allowing it to climb and spread along the ground or other vegetation. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly affect the growth and survival of its host plants.
